segment.source: 5059(S, F) Key migration operation.
segment.target: 5059(S, F) Key migration operation.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 5059(S, F) Key migration operation.
segment.target: Describes security event 5059(S, F) Key migration operation.

segment.source: 5059(S, F): Key migration operation.
segment.target: 5059(S, F): Key migration operation.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates when a cryptographic key is exported or imported using a Key Storage Provider (KSP).
segment.target: This event generates when a cryptographic key is exported or imported using a Key Storage Provider (KSP).

segment.source: This event generates only if one of the following KSPs were used:
segment.target: This event generates only if one of the following KSPs were used:

segment.source: Microsoft Software Key Storage Provider
segment.target: Microsoft Software Key Storage Provider

segment.source: Microsoft Smart Card Key Storage Provider
segment.target: Microsoft Smart Card Key Storage Provider

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: None.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: None.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Subject:
segment.target: Subject:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested key migration operation.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested key migration operation.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested key migration operation.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested key migration operation.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Cryptographic Parameters:
segment.target: Cryptographic Parameters:

segment.source: Provider Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of KSP through which the operation was performed.
segment.target: Provider Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of KSP through which the operation was performed.

segment.source: Can have one of the following values:
segment.target: Can have one of the following values:

segment.source: Microsoft Software Key Storage Provider
segment.target: Microsoft Software Key Storage Provider

segment.source: Microsoft Smart Card Key Storage Provider
segment.target: Microsoft Smart Card Key Storage Provider

segment.source: Algorithm Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of cryptographic algorithm through which the key was used or accessed.
segment.target: Algorithm Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of cryptographic algorithm through which the key was used or accessed.

segment.source: For “Read persisted key from file” operation, this typically has “UNKNOWN” value.
segment.target: For “Read persisted key from file” operation, this typically has “UNKNOWN” value.

segment.source: Can also have one of the following values:
segment.target: Can also have one of the following values:

segment.source: RSA – algorithm created by Ron Rivest, Adi Shamir, and Leonard Adleman.
segment.target: RSA – algorithm created by Ron Rivest, Adi Shamir, and Leonard Adleman.

segment.source: DSA – Digital Signature Algorithm.
segment.target: DSA – Digital Signature Algorithm.

segment.source: DH – Diffie-Hellman.
segment.target: DH – Diffie-Hellman.

segment.source: ECDHP521 – Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman algorithm with 512-bit key length.
segment.target: ECDHP521 – Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman algorithm with 512-bit key length.

segment.source: ECDHP384 – Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman algorithm with 384-bit key length.
segment.target: ECDHP384 – Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman algorithm with 384-bit key length.

segment.source: ECDHP256 – Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman algorithm with 256-bit key length.
segment.target: ECDHP256 – Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman algorithm with 256-bit key length.

segment.source: ECDSAP256 – Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm with 256-bit key length.
segment.target: ECDSAP256 – Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm with 256-bit key length.

segment.source: ECDSAP384 – Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm with 384-bit key length.
segment.target: ECDSAP384 – Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm with 384-bit key length.

segment.source: ECDSAP521 – Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm with 521-bit key length.
segment.target: ECDSAP521 – Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm with 521-bit key length.

segment.source: Key Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the key (key container) with which operation was performed.
segment.target: Key Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the key (key container) with which operation was performed.

segment.source: For example, to get the list of Key Names for certificates for logged in user you can use “certutil -store -user my” command and check Key Container parameter in the output.
segment.target: For example, to get the list of Key Names for certificates for logged in user you can use “certutil -store -user my” command and check Key Container parameter in the output.

segment.source: Here is an output example:
segment.target: Here is an output example:

segment.source: Key Type Type = UnicodeString: can have one of the following values:
segment.target: Key Type Type = UnicodeString: can have one of the following values:

segment.source: “User key.”
segment.target: “User key.”

segment.source: – user’s cryptographic key.
segment.target: – user’s cryptographic key.

segment.source: “Machine key.”
segment.target: “Machine key.”

segment.source: – machine’s cryptographic key.
segment.target: – machine’s cryptographic key.

segment.source: Additional Information:
segment.target: Additional Information:

segment.source: Operation Type = UnicodeString: performed operation.
segment.target: Operation Type = UnicodeString: performed operation.

segment.source: Examples:
segment.target: Examples:

segment.source: “Export of persistent cryptographic key.”
segment.target: “Export of persistent cryptographic key.”

segment.source: – typically generates during key read operations, which means that the key was taken for read purposes.
segment.target: – typically generates during key read operations, which means that the key was taken for read purposes.

segment.source: But it also generates during real key export operations (export certificate with private key, for example).
segment.target: But it also generates during real key export operations (export certificate with private key, for example).

segment.source: “Import of persistent cryptographic key.”
segment.target: “Import of persistent cryptographic key.”

segment.source: – key import operation was performed (import certificate with private key, for example).
segment.target: – key import operation was performed (import certificate with private key, for example).

segment.source: Return Code Type = HexInt32: has “0x0” value for Success events.
segment.target: Return Code Type = HexInt32: has “0x0” value for Success events.

segment.source: For failure events, provides a hexadecimal error code number.
segment.target: For failure events, provides a hexadecimal error code number.

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 5059(S, F): Key migration operation.
segment.target: For 5059(S, F): Key migration operation.

segment.source: Typically this event is required for detailed monitoring of KSP-related actions with cryptographic keys.
segment.target: Typically this event is required for detailed monitoring of KSP-related actions with cryptographic keys.

segment.source: If you need to monitor actions related to specific cryptographic keys (“Key Name”) or a specific “Operation”, such as “Export of persistent cryptographic key”, create monitoring rules and use this event as an information source.
segment.target: If you need to monitor actions related to specific cryptographic keys (“Key Name”) or a specific “Operation”, such as “Export of persistent cryptographic key”, create monitoring rules and use this event as an information source.

segment.source: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.
segment.target: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.
